title: 113_hr1267
content: The Flood Insurance Premium Relief Act of 2013 delays premium rate increases for certain properties. The Flood Insurance Premium Relief Act of 2013 delays premium rate increases for newly purchased properties between July 6, 2012, and January 1, 2015. The risk premium rate charged for flood insurance during the first 12 months after purchase remains the same as before purchase, with subsequent rates not less than estimated under the National Flood Insurance Act. The Flood Insurance Premium Relief Act of 2013 delays premium rate increases for newly purchased properties between July 6, 2012, and January 1, 2015. Any increase in flood insurance rates for properties after the initial 12-month period is phased in over a 10-year period at a rate of 10 percent per year. Properties covered by flood insurance on the date of a new rate map update are also subject to delayed implementation of rate changes. The risk premium rate for flood insurance may increase due to a map update. The rate will remain the same for the first 12 months after the update, and any subsequent increase will be phased in over a 10-year period at a rate of 10 percent per year. The term "covered flood insurance rate map update" refers to any revision or updating of flood insurance rate maps under specific acts between July 6, 2012, and January 1, 2015, with subsequent rate increases phased in over a 10-year period at 10 percent per year. SEC. 3. PERMANENT PHASE-IN OF PREMIUM RATE INCREASES FOR CERTAIN PROPERTIES. Properties purchased in 2015 or later will have flood insurance premium rate increases phased in over a 10-year period, at a rate of 10 percent each year. Properties with new flood insurance rate maps effective in 2015 or later will also be affected by these changes. The Insurance Premium Relief Act of 2013 amends the rate of increase for flood insurance premiums for properties purchased in 2015 or later, extending the phase-in period to a 10-year period at a rate of 10 percent each year.
